textBeforeTable: Number of Slaves was 10,002 769 Slaveholders 1,359 farms of 500-999 acres 82 farms of over 999 acres 1860 Troup County population included 6,223 Whites, 37 "Free Colored" and 10,002 slaves 1870 Troup County population included 6,408 Whites, and 11,224 "Colored" Slaveholder listings by number of Slaves Submitted by C. W. Barnum Source: University of Virginia Library 1860 was the last year that slaves were held and thus reported on the census. In the 1870 census, free Blacks were enumerated, but the majority did not use the surnames of former slaveholders. A complicating factor for research is the fact  a migration of former slaves took place after the Civil War to other counties and other states such as Texas, Alabama, North Carolina, Florida, Ohio, Indiana, and Kansas according to Tom Blake, author of  the Largest Slaveholder Project in 2002. Mr. Blade reported these facts for the 1860 Slaveholder Schedule fro Troup County. The 1860 Census did not mention the names of African Americans unless they were Free. The 1860 for Troup County only had thirty-seven free Blacks listed. The 1860 Slave Schedule listed the names of the Slaveholders, but not the names of the slaves. This exhibit shows those Slaveholders to enable researchers to find evidence of an ancestor through the slaveholder data.  By finding surname of the Slaveholder, a researcher may then examine the actual slave schedule for additional information gender and age of the slaves.
